content.text:
# List of pilots awarded an Aviator's Certificate by the Royal Aero Club in 1912

The Royal Aero Club issued Aviators Certificates from 1910. These were internationally recognised under the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale.
List
{| class="wikitable"
|-
!colspan=5 | Aviator's Certificates awarded
|-
|align="center"|in 1910(1–38)
|align="center"|in 1911(39–168)
|align="center"|in 1912(169–382)
|align="center"|in 1913(383–719)
|align="center"|in 1914(720–1032)
|}
Legend
{| class="wikitable"
|+ Royal Aero Club certificates awarded in 1912 (nos. 169–382)
! width="5%" |No. !! width="20%" |Name !! width="16%" |Date !! width="59%" |Comment
|-
| align="center" |169
| Lt. Garthshore Tindal Porter RA
| align="center" | 9 January 1912
| (1887–1957) Australian-born. Used a Bristol Biplane at Salisbury Plain. Born in Queensland Colony before joining the British Army. Served in the Royal Garrison Artillery, the Royal Flying Corps and Royal Air Force. Died in Cheltenham.
|-
| align="center" |170
| Lt. Amyas Eden Borton, Black Watch
| align="center" | 9 January 1912
| (1886–1969) Used a Bristol Biplane at Salisbury Plain. Served in the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Air Force. Retired as an Air Vice-Marshal, in 1933.
|-
| align="center" |171
| Benjamin Graham Wood
| align="center" | 9 January 1912
| (1883–1967) An engineer. Used a Hewlett and Blondeau Farman biplane at Brooklands.
|-
| align="center" |172
| Sydney Vincent Sippe
| align="center" | 9 January 1912
| Used an Avro biplane at Brooklands. Flew with the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service. On 21 November 1914 he attacked the Zeppelin sheds at Lake Constance. Sippe was awarded the Distinguished Service Order in 1915, he died in 1968.
|-
| align="center" |173
| Tom Garne
| align="center" | 16 January 1912
| Used a Bristol biplane at Brooklands.
|-
| align="center" |174
| align="left"|Lt. Napier John Gill
| align="center" | 16 January 1912
| Author of [https://archive.org/stream/flyersguideeleme00gillrich#page/n0/mode/2up "The Flyer's Guide: An Elementary Handbook for Aviators"], 1917.
|-
| align="center" |175
| Frederick Bernard Fowler
| align="center" | 16 January 1912
| Founded the Eastbourne Aviation Company; in 1919, at the rank of major, he was awarded the AFC (UK). He was also a member of the 1921 Sempill Mission to Japan, for which he was awarded the Order of the Rising Sun (4th Class)
|-
| align="center" |176
| Lt. Alan Geoffrey Fox RE
| align="center" | 30 January 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |177
| Lt. Eric Mackay Murray
| align="center" | 30 January 1912
|1886–1954Served in the Royal Flying Corps and was awarded the Military Cross and the Distinguished Service Order, retired in 1933 as a Group Captain in the Royal Air Force.
|-
| align="center" |178
| Giovanni Sabelli
| align="center" | 30 January 1912
| (1886–1917) Italian. Used a Deperdussin Monoplane at Brooklands. Killed in action over the Bainsizza Plateau.
|-
| align="center" |179
| Frederick Warren Merriam
| align="center" | 6 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |180
| William Bendall
| align="center" | 6 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |181
| Eng. Lt. Charles Russell Jekyl Randall
| align="center" | 13 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |182
| Capt. Thomas Weeding
| align="center" | 13 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |183
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Damer Leslie Allen
| align="center" | 20 February 1912
| Disappeared while attempting to cross the Irish Channel from Holyhead on 18 April 1912.
|-
| align="center" |184
| Sydney Parr
| align="center" | 20 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |185
| Lt. Bertram Richard White Beor RFA
| align="center" | 20 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |186
| Marcel Desoutter
| align="center" | 27 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |187
| Lt. Stephen Christopher Winfield-Smith
| align="center" | 27 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |188
| Lt. Cecil Thomas Carfrae RFA
| align="center" | 27 February 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |189
| Herbert Dennis Cutler
| align="center" | 5 March 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |190
| style="background:#999999;" | Victor Annesley Barrington-Kennett
| align="center" | 5 March 1912
| (1887–1916). 2nd Lt in the London Balloon Corps used a Short biplane at Eastchurch. Killed in action flying a Bristol Scout on 13 Mar 1916 in Flanders while serving as a Major and commanding officer of No. 4 Squadron Royal Flying Corps. Three of the four brothers were killed in the Great War (see entry: No. 43).
|-
| align="center" |191
| Lt. Clement Gordon Wakefield Head RN
| align="center" | 5 March 1912
| -Lt. Cmdr of HM Submarine D2 which was rammed and sunk by German Patrol boat in the North Sea off Borkum Island on 25 November 1914. Memorial on Portsmouth Naval Memorial for Officers killed in 1914 and in Seaford Cemetery.
|-
| align="center" |192
| Lt. Charles Longcroft
| align="center" | 5 March 1912
| RFC pilot, squadron, wing and brigade commander during World War I. First Commandant of the RAF College Cranwell.
|-
| align="center" |193
| Cyril Wright Meredith
| align="center" | 5 March 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |194
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Capt. Patrick Hamilton
| align="center" | 12 March 1912
| Died in a crash in Deperdussin Monoplane 100 Gnome No. 258 at Graveley, near Welwyn, on 6 September 1912. Passenger Lieut. A. Wyness-Stuart (Aviator's Certificate no. 141) was also killed. The accident was considered to have been caused by "a part of the engine coming off and hitting the bonnet over the engine, smashing one of the wing wires, and thus loosening the wings".
|-
| align="center" |195
| Cecil J. L'Estrange Malone
| align="center" | 12 March 1912
| Pioneer naval aviator and Britain's first communist member of the House of Commons
|-
| align="center" |196
| style="background:#999999;" | Major George Hebden Raleigh, Essex Regiment
| align="center" | 12 March 1912
| (1878–1915) Australian. Used a Bristol Monoplane at Brooklands, killed in action 21 January 1915 off Belgian Coast, flying a Vickers FB5. Born in Melbourne and educated at Geelong Grammar School, before joining the British Army and serving in the 2nd Boer War:  Queen's South Africa Medal and 8 clasps.
|-
| align="center" |197
| Ronald Louis Charteris
| align="center" | 12 March 1912
| Used a Deperdussin Monoplane at Brooklands, an aeronautical engineer with the All British Engine Company.
|-
| align="center" |198
| George Prensiell
| align="center" | 19 March 1912
| A German engineer, used a Bleriot Monoplane at Hendon.
|-
| align="center" |199
| William Ewart Hart
| align="center" | 26 March 1912
| (1885–1943) An Australian aviator who was the first to qualify in Australia, holding an Australian aviator's licence no.1, dated 5 December 1911.
|-
| align="center" |200
| Capt. Francis John Brodigan
| align="center" |26 March 1912
| 1st Gloucester Regiment (infantry), who was killed in action on 9 May 1915 at Aubers Ridge.
|-
| align="center" |201
| Lt. Alexander Ernest Burchardt-Ashton, 4th Dragoon Guards
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| Used a Bristol Biplane at Larkhill, Salisbury Plain. He hit and killed a 15-year-old boy at Larkhill in May 1912 when he landed too fast and ran into the crowd. Because of a lack of brakes at the time it was deemed an accidental death. He resigned his commission in 1915, and was killed in action in France on 11 July 1916 as a Lance Corporal with the Royal Fusiliers.
|-
| align="center" |202
| Lt. F. A. P. Williams-Freeman RN
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |203
| Com. O. Schwann RN
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |204
| Capt. P. W. L. Broke-Smith RE
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| Awarded Airship Pilot's Certificate No. 2 on 14 February 1911
|-
| align="center" |205
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. L. C. Rogers Harrison
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| Killed in air crash in a Cody V biplane on 28 April 1913 at Farnborough
|-
| align="center" |206
| Sub.-Lt. C. H. K. Edmonds RN
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| Awarded the DSO for his role in the Cuxhaven Raid in 1914; in 1917 made the first successful aerial torpedo attack i.e. from a Short Seaplane against a Turkish ship. He was an Air Vice Marshal during World War II.
|-
| align="center" |207
| D. G. Young
| align="center" | 16 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |208
| Lucien Alfred Tremlett
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
| Born in Paris in 1887 he took his certificate on a Bleriot Monoplane at Hendon.
|-
| align="center" |209
| Lt. John Dolben Mackworth
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
| Born in Wales in 1887 he took his certificate on a Bristol Biplane at Brooklands. Later a lieutenant-colonel in the Royal Flying Corps involved with the development of ballons and kite balloons, he died in 1939.
|-
| align="center" |210
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Esme Fairfax Chinnery
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
|  Coldstream Guards and Royal Flying Corps, killed in an aircraft accident in France on 18 January 1915
|-
| align="center" |211
| John Robertson Duigan
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |212
| Lt. H. C. Fielding
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |213
| Major Sir Alexander Bannerman, Bart., RE
| align="center" | 30 April 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |214
| Lt. Alan Hartree RFA
| align="center" | 14 May 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |215
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Gordon Strachey Shephard
| align="center" | 14 May 1912
| Rose quickly to the rank of Brigadier-General at age 32; Commanding Officer of 1st Brigade R.F.C, died 19 January 1918, when his Nieuport Scout span into the ground.
|-
| align="center" |216
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Donald Swain Lewis RE
| align="center" | 14 May 1912
| Died on an inspection flight in France in 1916.
|-
| align="center" |217
| Capt. Godfrey Paine RN
| align="center" | 14 May 1912
| First commandant of the Central Flying School at RAF Upavon; he attained the ranks of Major-General, Rear-Admiral and Air Vice-Marshal, possibly the only person to have held flag, general and air officer ranks in the British armed services; he was also Inspector-General of the RAF and 5th Sea Lord/Director of Naval Aviation
|-
| align="center" |218
| Henry Charles Baird
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |219
| Hugh Percy Nesham
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |220
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Charles Lindsay-Campbell
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| Killed at Brooklands in a Bristol monoplane on 3 August 1912 when the aircraft stalled after engine failure.
|-
| align="center" |221
| Francis Henry Fowler
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |222
| Thomas O'Brien Hubbard
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| 1882–1962 Served with the Royal Flying Corps and Royal Air Force 1914–1921, awarded the Military Cross and Air Force Cross, retired as a Royal Air Force Group Captain.
|-
| align="center" |223
| Montague Righton Nevill Jennings
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| 1890–1976 Served with the Royal Flying Corps and was awarded the Military Cross and Air Force Cross in 1918, later served with the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve during the Second World War.
|-
| align="center" |224
| Alphonse Potet
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| A French mechanic used a Bleriot Monoplane at Hendon.
|-
| align="center" |225
| style="background:#999999;" | Richard Thomas Gates
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| Former Yeomanry officer he used a Howard-Wright Biplane at Hendon. Became general manager of the Grahame-White factory at Hendon, he was given a special duty commission in the Royal Naval Air Service at the start of the first world war. Died of injuries on 14 September 1914 a few days after his Henry Farman biplane crashed at Hendon returning from an anti-Zeppelin patrol.
|-
| align="center" |226
| Lt. David Percival RGA
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |227
| 2nd.-Corporal Frank Ridd RE
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
|  Using a Bristol Biplane at Salisbury Plain he becomes the first non-commissioned officer to become a pilot. A former Bricklayer before he joined the Royal Engineers, he had transferred to the Royal Flying Corps in May 1912 and moved to the Royal Air Force on 1 April 1918 where he was a Carpenter and Rigger.
|-
| align="center" |228
| Lt. Leonard Dawes
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
|  2nd Middlesex Regiment, served with the Royal Flying Corps and Royal Air Force during the Great War before returning to the Army. Appointed a Chevalier of the Legion of Honour by the French in November 1914.
|-
| align="center" |229
| Lt. J. N. Fletcher RE
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |230
| style="background:#999999;" | Lt. Baron Trevenen James RE
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
|  Killed in action 13 July 1915 with 6 Squadron RFC.
|-
| align="center" |231
| Marcus Dyce Manton
| align="center" | 4 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |232
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Staff-Sergeant Richard H. V. Wilson RE
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| Died in a crash on Salisbury Plain 5 July 1912, in a Nieuport piloted by Eustace B. Loraine.
|-
| align="center" |233
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Desmond L. Arthur
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| Died on the morning of 27 May 1913 at Montrose when the upper starboard wing of his aircraft, a B.E. Biplane (No 205), broke, causing both starboard planes to collapse progressively. The Accident Investigation Committee decided that the primary cause of the accident was the failure of a faulty joint in a repair to the rear main spar. The Committee expressed the opinion "that the repair referred to was (...) so badly done that it could not possibly be regarded as the work of a conscientious and competent workman."
|-
| align="center" |234
| Lt. Ercole Ercole
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| Italian Army aviator used a Bristol biplane at Larkhill, Salisbury Plain.
|-
| align="center" |235
| Paul Dubois
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |236
| Capt. John Harold Whitworth Becke
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| Royal Flying Corps aviator used a Bristol Biplane at Brooklands. Retired from the Royal Air Force as a brigadier-general in 1920.
|-
| align="center" |237
| Norman S. Roupell
| align="center" | 18 June 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |238
| Edward H. Morriss
| align="center" | 18 June 1912

| Ronald Hargrave Kershaw
| align="center" | 16 July 1912
| Royal Naval Air Service aviator used a Howard Wright biplane at Hendon, later a Group Captain in the Royal Air Force, died in 1969.
|-

| K. R. Shaw
| align="center" | 16 July 1912

| align="center" | 24 July 1912

| align="center" |253
| Air Mechanic William Victor Strugnell
| align="center" | 24 July 1912
|  Royal Flying Corps, a First World War flying ace he was credited with six aerial victories, retired as a Royal Air Force Group Captain in 1945.  He was awarded a Military Cross in 1914 and a bar in 1917.
|-
| align="center" |254
| Lt. F. M. Worthington-Wilmer
| align="center" | 24 July 1912
| –

| align="center" | 24 July 1912
| –

| align="center" |256
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Claude Albemarle Bettington
| align="center" | 24 July 1912
| Killed on 10 September 1912, as a passenger of Edward Hotchkiss, when their Bristol Monoplane crashed due to the failure of a quick release cable fitment, which caused the fabric of the starboard wing to fail.
|-
| align="center" |257
| Capt. Charles Darbyshire
| align="center" | 24 July 1912

| Lt. Francis FitzGerald Waldron
| align="center" | 24 July 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |261
| style="background:#999999;" | Herbert Rutter Simms
| align="center" | 24 July 1912
| Used an Avro Biplane at The Roe School, Brooklands. Killed in action as a Flight Sub-Lieutenant, Royal Naval Air Service off the Belgian Coast 5 May 1916.
|-
| align="center" |262
| Pte. John Edmonds RMLI
| align="center" | 30 July 1912
| –

| Sidney Pickles

| Maj. John Frederick Andrews Higgins RFA
| align="center" | 30 July 1912
| –
|-
| align="center" |265
| Eng. Lt. Edward Featherstone Briggs RN
| align="center" |30 July 1912
| Led the bombing raid on the Zeppelin Base at Friedrichshafen on 21 November 1914. Shot down and wounded by anti-aircraft fire and became a POW. Served in the RAF after the war and retired with the rank of Group Captain. Died in 1962.
|-
| align="center" |266
| Capt. Charles Percy Nicholas IA
| align="center" | 30 July 1912
| –

| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Air Mechanic William Thomas James McCudden
| align="center" | 13 August 1912
| Used a Bristol Biplane at the Army School, Salisbury Plain. He was the elder brother of James McCudden VC. Died when his Bleriot had engine trouble on 1 May 1915 at Fort Grange.
|-
| align="center" |270
| Maj. Hugh Montague Trenchard
| align="center" | 13 August 1912
| Later to command the Royal Flying Corps in France and serve as first Chief of the Air Staff
|-

| Lt. Reginald Cholmondeley
| align="center" |13 August 1912
| –
|-

| Capt. John Maitland Salmond
| align="center" | 13 August 1912
| A Captain in the King's Own Royal Lancaster Regiment he used a Grahame-White Biplane at the Grahame-White School at Hendon. Marshal of the Royal Air Force Sir John Maitland Salmond retired from the Royal Air Force in 1943 and he died in 1968.
|-
| align="center" |273
| Capt. Alister Maxwell MacDonell
| align="center" | 13 August 1912
| –

| align="center" | 13 August 1912

| align="center" | 3 September 1912

| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Lt. Gilbert Vernon Wildman-Lushington RMA
| align="center" | 17 September 1912
| Died when the Maurice-Farman aircraft he was flying at Eastchurch side-slipped and crashed on Tuesday, 2 December 1913. His passenger, Capt. Fawcett, RM, survived, suffering a broken collarbone. On the previous Saturday, Wildman-Lushington had taken the then First Lord of the Admiralty, Winston Churchill, for a series of three flying lessons in a Short Brothers S.38 biplane, during the third of which Churchill took the controls for a time, making him the first serving Cabinet minister to have flown an aeroplane.
|-

| align="center" | 17 September 1912

| align="center" | 17 September 1912

| align="center" |330
| style="background:#e3d9ff;" | Paymaster Eustace R. Berne RN
| align="center" | 15 October 1912
| E.R. Berne died on 21 April 1913 on the ground at Eastchurch, when an aircraft with Gilbert V. Wildman-Lushington (see #290 above) at the controls suddenly ran forward, knocking him down and catching his legs with the propeller. Berne died from loss of blood and shock two and a half hours after the accident.

| Vincent Patrick Taylor
| align="center" | 17 December 1912
| Born in Sydney, New South Wales in 1874 he took his certificate on a Bristol Biplane at the Bristol School, Salisbury Plain. He later performed balloon and parachute stunts around Australia using the name "Captain Taylor Penfold". He died in 1930.
